Actinomadura rugatobispora is a species of actinobacteria that belongs to the genus Actinomadura. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium.

The cells of A. rugatobispora are typically rod-shaped and exhibit a characteristic wrinkled (rugose) appearance on the surface of their spores. The spores are produced in a zigzag pattern, which is a distinctive feature of this species.

Actinomadura rugatobispora is known to be a soil-dwelling bacterium, commonly isolated from various terrestrial environments. It is capable of degrading complex organic compounds, such as cellulose and chitin, due to the production of various hydrolytic enzymes.

This species has been the subject of interest in the field of biotechnology and natural product discovery, as it has the potential to produce bioactive secondary metabolites with potential pharmaceutical or industrial applications.
